posts.name: Javaru
posts.cooked: Working on our autonomous modes, I’ve noticed that DriverStation.getAlliance()) – in java – is always returning Red regardless of what value is set for the “Team Station” on the Driver Station. Digging a little further, DriverStationJNI.getAllianceStation()) is always returning Red1 regardless of what value is  set for the “Team Station” on the Driver Station. Is anyone else experiencing this behavior? We’ve tried rebooting everything without success.

link_counts.title: Should Optionals be used by WPILib?

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked: Is this on Sim or on the roboRIO? Also in a unit test, or just in a normal robot program?

posts.name: Javaru
posts.cooked: This is running normal (i.e. non-test) robot code on the roboRIO.

posts.name: jdao
posts.cooked: Where are you grabbing this in code? Are you constantly reading this value or are you only getting it once?

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked: Just double checked, and this works just fine. If you connect OutlineViewer, is the FMSInfo table correct? It has the alliance station in it.

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked:
One thing I forgot, is that reading in RobotInit currently does not work at all right now, and will always return red1. It needs to be read later. A fix is going into the next WPILib release that will let it work on robotInit.

But either way, reading in robotInit is wrong, as its extremely likely robot code will come up before the DS connects on the field.

posts.name: Javaru
posts.cooked: I was getting it one time during robotInit() . I just added logging to autonomousInit() to grab and log the values… it is reporting the correct values during autonomousInit()

posts.name: Javaru
posts.cooked: Thanks Thad. I’ll move the work to autonmousInit() .

posts.name: vargoose84
posts.cooked: Is there a is FMS connected variable that can be read?

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked:
Yes. DriverStation.isFMSAttached will give that info. But there’s no need for that. The alliance station will always be correct in autonomousInit(), and we don’t guarantee any other function runs before that, other than robotInit(). You also won’t get an update if you put a blocking wait in robotInit().

TL;DR the state can go from off → robotInit → autonomousInit without ever touching any of the disabled calls. So it wouldn’t be safe to put the check anywhere but autonomousInit. The only safe place to put a check for that kind of data is in the init() functions for the mode that needs it.

posts.name: Paul Rensing
posts.cooked:
So, I understand what you are saying about “guarantee”, but it does present a particular challenge this year with the AprilTags.

In our Drivetrain.periodic() command, we check if the vision system found a Tag, and if so, update the PoseEstimator. In theory this should work well to refine the initial position. If the robot is sitting on the field for minutes, turned on, while the match is set up and ready to go, then we should have a reasonably accurate pose when the match starts. However, obviously, if we were actually on Red and did not adjust the field orientation, it would be a wrong pose. Switching the coordinates (only) at in autoInit() would reek havoc, with the vision poses suddenly all the way across the field, and the robot struggling to try to follow a crazy and confused trajectory.

So, I assume we can try to set the field orientation earlier. What is the correct way to know if the setting should be correct? DriverStation has isFMSConnected and isDSConnected; does the Alliance color come from the FMS or from the DS?

[edit] Just to clarify: Most teams will choose their Auto routine using Shuffleboard once their robot is connected on the field and their DS can talk to their robot. If that is true, presumably the Alliance color fetched by the robot will be correct? Is that correct?

posts.name: Jason Daming
posts.cooked:
Correcting pose from an AprilTag reading doesn’t require alliance color.

The tags are unique if you accurately see a tag you know where you are. It sounds like you are merging tags or something.

Why are you switching coordinates?  This year’s field isn’t rotationally symmetric.

No we can’t guarantee alliance color until match start. It should be before then but don’t risk it.

posts.name: Paul Rensing
posts.cooked:
OK, this is confusing.

Yes, the field is not rotationally symmetric. That is the whole point of why we do need to switch the coordinates; well, actually, which the origin of the coordinate system.  The coordinate rotation of the AprilTag layout was provided so that the robot could work relative to its Alliance station origin, not relative to the global origin. Otherwise, all the autonomous trajectories, etc, would need to be rotated based on Alliance color.

If the robot sees tag 1 and is 1m directly in front of it, and it is on the Blue Alliance, then it is at roughly (1m, 2m) on the field (sorry, making up those numbers). If it is on the Red Alliance, then that would be coordinates across the field.

If the Alliance color can’t be known until the very start of the match, that really sucks and teams should be alerted to that in big flashing letters.

posts.name: Jason Daming
posts.cooked:
prensing:

Otherwise, all the autonomous trajectories, etc, would need to be rotated based on Alliance color.

This is the answer.  See what PathPlanner is doing.  I would tend to use the word reflected across the center line not rotated.

You are instead changing the coordinates of the tags based on alliance color, which you would see can’t even run the same trajectories as the other alliance because their spots aren’t the same relative to the objects on the field you are interacting with.  There is canned code you can use to do the reflection just use that and save the headache of flipping coordinate system for no gain.

posts.name: Paul Rensing
posts.cooked:
jdaming:

This is the answer. See what PathPlanner is doing. I would tend to use the word reflected across the center line not rotated.

It is definitely a rotation, not a reflection. If that were a reflection, the Blue and Red scoring stations would be directly across the field from each other. They are not. I suppose you could say it is flipped through the center point of the field, but that is a rotation.

I do disagree with your point about the trajectories. In all games including this one, the Auto trajectories work just fine on both sides of the field as long as the robot is set up pointing in the right direction relative to the appropriate driver station wall. The difference this year is the absolute Tag locations, which WPILib gave an apparent fix with “setOrigin()”.

Also, this does feel like WPILib did not create a “sensible” or consistent interface. If flipping the origin of the AprilTags is a bad idea, then why add that feature to the AprilTagLayout? Oh well.

Even more relevant, maybe the docs for DriverStation need to be supplemented. If the fetched values cannot be relied on until autoInit(), then it should clearly state that.

I will look into flipping the trajectories, or some other solution.

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked:
I thought the PathPlanner flip was meant to work with a flipped coordinate system.  That is regardless of alliance 0,0 is right side of driver station wall.   When it loads red it transforms the rotations and y coordinates, but if you are using april tags for pose estimation it would require you used alliance transformed april tags for pose estimation, because as was pointed out if you always have 0,0 on your right ds wall tag 1 is in a different location depending on alliance.

Is this right @mjansen4857 ?

Also @Thad_House though it may not be safe now will Robot.autonomousInit() be the right/safe place to get your april tag field layout origin set?

posts.name: Ryan Blue
posts.cooked:
Bmongar:

Also @Thad_House though it may not be safe now will Robot.autonomousInit() be the right/safe place to get your april tag field layout origin set?

autonomousInit has been, and will continue to be a safe place to check for alliance color. You wouldn’t really want to rely on checking at robotInit anyway, because the driver station may or may not be connected when the code boots.

posts.name: Michael Jansen
posts.cooked:
prensing:

It is definitely a rotation, not a reflection. If that were a reflection, the Blue and Red scoring stations would be directly across the field from each other. They are not.

It is reflected, and the scoring positions are directly across from each other: image 1218×610 59.1 KB

image 1218×610 59.1 KB

image 1218×610 59.1 KB

prensing:

I do disagree with your point about the trajectories. In all games including this one, the Auto trajectories work just fine on both sides of the field as long as the robot is set up pointing in the right direction relative to the appropriate driver station wall.

So, therefore, this is untrue. Say you wanted to score a preloaded game piece in the position closest to the loading zone then drive to the charging station and balance. In order to do this on the blue alliance, you would need to drive to the right (-Y) to get to the charging station. On the red alliance, you would need to drive to the left (+Y) to do the same thing.

Bmongar:

Is this right @mjansen4857 ?

So yeah, this is correct.

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked:
On the field, once either isDsConnected or isFmsConnected goes true, the data is valid. On the field those 2 variables are synced, and you can’t have 1 without the other.

As for when to check, the problem is where. Generally you could check in something ram from robotPeriodic, but it’s possible there is a case where robotPeriodic doesn’t run a single time before autonomousInit. How I probably would do it is check both places. Check in robotPeriodic which will work in 99% of cases, but then also check in autonomousInit if it hasn’t been set by robotPeriodic.

robotPeriodic can be safe, I would just also do a sanity check in autonomousInit. robotPeriodic is safe probably 99.9% of the time on the field. robotInit however is probably safe 0.01% of the time on the field, so I would very much recommend never reading ds data in robotInit.

posts.name: Bryn Dole - programming mentor FRC 2930
posts.cooked:
Thad_House:

Generally you could check in something ram from robotPeriodic, but it’s possible there is a case where robotPeriodic doesn’t run a single time before autonomousInit.

As noted by others, the alliance color impacts PathPlanner trajectory generation and thus affects autonomous commands generated on startup. I’ve seen many robot implementations (including our own in the past) that will populate the dashboard Chooser  with commands. My thought experiment is, if the chooser is instantiated during robotInit and gets the wrong alliance color, will you end up with incorrect PathPlanner trajectories when on the blue alliance (assuming it defaults to Red)?

If this is the case, you need to delay populating the chooser until the alliance color is know and re-populate the chooser if the alliance color changes (only during testing one hopes).

I have a suspicion that the large number or 2022 autonomous routines in our chooser was impacting startup time of our robot. It was building and loading 10+ complicated autons w/ multiple trajectories. I was investigating ways to delay instantiating auton commands only if selected and doing it before autonInit was called to prevent wasting precious time during autonomous.

This all seems too convoluted to me. I’m hoping it’s just a lack of understanding on my part.

What is considered the standard safe practice for autonomous choosers?
